Diet & Body Re-composition

Initial Body Fat and Body Composition Changes

General Philosophies of Muscle Mass Gain

Sample Diets
Read the above articles, and decide whether you need to bulk (add muscle), cut (lose fat), or maintain.

Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) in calories

Bulking Diet:
Calories: TDEE + 500 calories
Protein: 1+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Cutting Diet:
Calories: TDEE - 500 calories
Protein: 1.5+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE
Protein: 1.25+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69250035
If you're skinny, don't worry deeply about what foods you're consuming as long as it is not complete junk 100% of the time. You're in need of calorie count and large amounts of protein more than anything. If you're fat, cut out the junk and eat below your average calorie count. That's probably the easiest blanket statement I've been able to come up with considering food when it comes to people. Skinny people need more big people need less if their goal is the opposite of where they're currently sitting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69250035
Dieting has the most amount of broscience/mommybloggers, misinformation, misleading studies by supplement companies or product pushers, as well as just a general lack of nutritional education from public education. It literally takes years to unlearn a lot of the complete horseshit that people have been taught.

Weight loss is going to be highly personalized for each person because, well, we're all built a little different. But the general truths hold up; CICO is king and there are no exceptions. Anyone saying otherwise is bending the truth or trying to hide it behind something misleading.

For example, a lot of people proclaim keto as the best fat loss diet, without needing to cut out fat from the diet. but at the end of the day, the weight loss comes mostly from calorie restriction, not some magic ketosis.

If you count your calories and are consistent, you will be able to manage your weight without issue.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69250035
Simplest way is this: Google "Gravitus lifting calculator" and input your measurements in there. It'll spit out estimations of how much carbs, fat, and protein your body needs, and how many calories to consume to lose X lbs a week.

That's it, just put together a diet that meets those requirements. You must hit your protein and fats goal, and use carbs to fill in the calorie gap, or cut carbs if you're going over your limit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69250035
>Some say skipping breakfast is good, some say it's bad.
Skipping breakfast reduces calorie intake, but also makes you hungrier later. It’s just another way of doing intermittent fasting.
>Some say you should cut off all fat, sugar, carbs some say you shouldn't.
Carbs are fine, added sugar and added fat is not. If you eat whole foods that have some sugar or fat in them naturally, you probably won’t be fat.
>Some recommend fasting, some say you should eat more frequently.
Fasting is fine as long as you eat at least once a day.
>Some say cheating and eating bad food in moderation is okay, some say it isn't.
It depends on your personality. Some people are addicted and can’t have any, some people can eat one cookie a day and not have anything else bad.
>Some say you just need to eat less calories than you burn, some say that doesn't work.
You need to eat less, eat protein, and eat nutritious food.
>Some say you should lose weight slowly, some say you should do it faster.
1-2 lb a week is fine.
>Some say you should try this diet, some say this one.
Join the fruit, vegetable, and lean meat cult. We have delicious salads here.

>Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
Prognosis can be affected by the type of genetic mutation that the person with CLL has.[78] Some examples of genetic mutations and their prognoses are: mutations in the IGHV region are associated with a median overall survival (OS) of more than 20–25 years, while no mutations in this region is associated with a median OS of 8–10 years; deletion of chromosome 13q is associated with a median OS of 17 years; and trisomy of chromosome 12, as well as deletion of chromosome 11q, is associated with a median OS of 9–11 years.[79] While prognosis is highly variable and dependent on various factors including these mutations, the average 5-year relative survival is 86.1%.[80] Telomere length has been suggested to be a valuable prognostic indicator of survival.[81] In addition, a person's sex has been found to have an impact on CLL prognosis and treatment efficacy. More specifically, females have been found to survive longer (without disease progression) than males, when treated with certain medications.[82]

Even if I can't contain the snail I would do it, but only if I got to know the snail's exact starting location.
Snails crawl at 3 inches per minute. That's 180 inches per hour == 15 feet per hour if they don't stop to rest or eat. That's 0.00284090909 (repeating) miles per hour.
In an entire YEAR it could travel only 3.545454 (repeating) miles.
If I live to 100 (another 72 years) it would only travel 255.27 miles in that time, assuming it moves in a straight line. I could just move a small east coast state over and I'd never have to worry about seeing it.

>Advice for new runners
- Try to keep your cadence high (at or around 180 steps per minute)
- Try to keep your heartrate in Zone1/2 (around an average of 55-65% of your max. heart rate)
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 mi. (10km), start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training routine for that race

>>69248716
Eggs, legumes (beans, peas, chickpeas), milk, some type of meat (cheapest would be tuna I suppose), tofu isn't massively expensive either. Frozen leafy greens and broccoli.

As a list ordering proteins from cheapest, highest quality to more expensive or lower quality it would be:
>eggs
>milk
>tuna (not higher due to heavy metals)
>legumes (incomplete alone but cheap and healthy to add to meals)
>frozen meats (very expensive right now)
>peanut butter (relatively inexpensive per serving, but higher in fat than protein)
>frozen green vegetables (cheap and has protein, but not very dense)

Always go with cheap whole foods. Minimally processed.

>>69249589
I fried chicken, fried onion and put a few asian things for flavor and sauce like söy sauce, oyster sauce, rice vinegar, ginger, garlic, sugar, chili, hoisin sauce. Also sesame seeds.
If you want to make a sauce like that, the simplest way is to mix söy sauce, sugar and either lime juice or rice vinegar until you taste and think that there's a perfect balance between salt, sweet and sour. Then when you learnt that basic feeling you can add other suitable asian things, my first recommendations would be ginger and garlic. Sesame oil is great for east asian flavor too.
Usually I make something like this but mix everything together with noodles instead of having it with rice. Putting a fried egg on top is good.

Mineral sunscreens are your best friend as they are 100% non-toxic, non-absorbing, and non-estrogenic; they're just zinc or titanium dioxide. But don't just buy the first one you find, as they have a way of sitting on top of the skin, white and opaque like clown makeup. I found a really good korean brand that sells a mineral-only sunscreen that both absorbs somewhat and is tinted so it's practically unnoticeable. Barring that, wearing a bucket hat and long-sleeved light shirts will go a long way. Luckily bucket hats are somewhat fashionable again at the moment, and sports companies like adidas and nike make good looking ones with wider brims that are both made of light materials and are vented, specifically for runners who want to keep the sun off their face but not burn up in the heat

>>69247290
These are steps I took which greatly improved my sleep:
>remove all caffeine and stimulants
Completely cut it out, not even in the morning. Caffeine/stimulants inhibit melatonin production so low melatonin producers can have sleep ruined even by a morning coffee.
>go to bed at the same time every night
>wake up at the same time every morning
This helps your body develop a consistent rhythm so you can get tired at the right time each night and be hormonally prepared for sleep.
>walk outside for ~20 minutes in the sun shortly after waking up
This kickstarts melatonin production. Contrary to what most people think, melatonin is produced slowly all day long and not just before bed time, so it's important to get full spectrum sunlight in your eyes to tell your body to get started on it.

If you do these things you'll set yourself up for much more consistent and deep sleep. You're waking up all the time because your body's hormonal cycles are out of whack.

posts.com:
>Who is /fat/ for?
For fatties who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

>>69249801
In all honesty being "satiated" for 4 hours isn't really being satiated at all. You're basically eating at regular intervals if you're eating every 4-6 hours. Eating once or twice a day while feeling full in between is entirely possible. While I agree with the protein poster I'd also like to add that you can train your ghrelin (hunger hormone) production. Your body adapts pretty quickly based on your eating habits so if you eat three times a day you'll feel hungry each day around those times. If you eat once a day you'll feel hungry around the time you usually eat. Your body and mind can easily adapt to eating less often and it is sustainable while trying to maintain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69240947
>even thin and fit people like my relatives seem worried
Well there's a couple things at play here. If you have lost a lot of weight rapidly they may be concerned because they've been told that it takes a long time to lose weight healthily. There is also the subconscious aspect of the pecking order. Whether people admit it or not, it does exist. By losing weight you've now changed your status. This will make persons who are insecure in their position worry that you losing weight will change the order of the system. You are likely the "fat relative" that people can use as a way to make them feel better about themselves. If you are no longer the "fat person" it affects their shitty coping mechanism and makes them uncomfortable.

You should definitely ignore anyone who questions your progress. Anyone who is happy for you will congratulate you or ask what you're doing. 90% of the time "concern" of this type is not warranted and is just a socially acceptable way to tell you that you need to stay in your lane. They do not care about you, they care about their own weirdo problems that are coming up for them when they see how you've changed.

Ignore these people anon, and keep reaching for your goal.

Right, let me say this really quickly.
I'm in my 40s, I've had long hair since I was 16.
I still look at myself in the mirror and think "Fuck Yeah" I love how I look.
BUT
There are two sorts of women out there.
Women who Like long hair on a man.
Women who Dislike long hair on a man.

For the women who Like long hair, you having short hair isn't a deal breaker, if they're talking with a nice looking short haired guy, they don't get turned off by the lack of long hair, it's just a Nice To Have.

For the women who Dislike long hair, it's likely that they HATE long hair on a man. Instant turn off. Even when they're stroking it at a party and saying "wow your hair is so great" what they often mean is "I wish my hair was this good, but I put a load of shitty dye in it and got a perm and then straightened it again and then used a curling iron on it, and they bleached it so I could dye it"
AND that's if you've got Good Long Hair.

My advice to a young man, thinking about his hairstyle's attractiveness to women, short, fashionable, brushed and combed, no oil, gel or goopy products. If current fashion seem to be heading for longer hair style, never go longer than collar length.

Shorter hair is more practical, washes faster, drys faster, doesn't get in the way. If you're thinking about women liking long hair... some might, but they'll be happy with short hair.

If you want long hair because "Fuck Yeah, I'm going for insane viking wizard aesthetic" or something... and you look in the mirror and love how you look, then do that for yourself.

>>69250663
The rest of the protein is absorbed, just more slowly than when cooked, and the beneficial nutrients in the yolk are highly heat sensitive (particularly the cholesterol which quickly oxidizes and degrades).
>Heating Has No Effect on the Net Protein Utilisation from Egg Whites in Rats: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5346405/
>Digestibility of Cooked and Raw Egg Protein in Humans as Assessed by Stable Isotope Techniques: https://academic.oup.com/jn/article/128/10/1716/4723080?login=false
In that second study, if you look at the graphs you'll notice that the cooked egg whites cause bigger spikes earlier on that drop off heavily while the raw egg whites have a lower overall value that's sustained much longer. So the protein is still all being absorbed but over a longer period of time, which isn't necessarily a bad thing.

It's about $6 for a dozen, pretty typical price. Check out your local farmer's markets and/or have a look on sites like localharvest.org to see what's near you.

>>69250954
>how is that efficient in any way?
It's less efficient but they only sell locally so that doesn't really matter like it would for some huge corporate operation. The Amish generally aren't after Infinite Growth (tm) in the first place like your average corporate capitalist and will even downsize their businesses if they become too successful. Maximum efficiency isn't necessary.
>why would someone do this?
Because they care about the welfare of their animals, it improves the quality and nutrition of the eggs, and eggs from chickens raised like this fetch a higher price.
>what about the male chicks culled at birth?
They're raised for meat and live with the hens until that time. The eggs are often fertilized but they're collected before any development can occur (fertilized eggs only develop embryos if they're kept at an appropriate temperature for long enough, keep them below 100F and they'll never develop even if fertilized). It's pretty much how chickens always were raised before the era of factory farming.

Here is some info on it
What are the risk factors for obstructive sleep apnea?

Certain anatomical characteristics are associated with an increased risk of obstructive sleep apnea. They include:

>Neck circumference larger than 17 inches (43 cm) for men

and 16 inches (40.5 cm) for women
Structural changes that prevent smooth airflow through the nose, such as a deviated septum
Certain variations of facial anatomy such as a short/recessed jaw, or an enlarged tongue or tonsils

Weight: A body mass index (BMI) exceeding 35 confers a significantly increased risk of obstructive sleep apnea, although people with a BMI below this level can still have the condition.

Age & Sex: The highest incidence of sleep apnea occurs beginning in middle age. Men are at higher risk than women, at least until women go through menopause.

High Blood Pressure: those with obstructive sleep apnea are more likely to have high blood pressure. This is because untreated sleep apnea itself can cause high blood pressure.

Family history: If one or more of your parents have sleep apnea, that increases your risk for developing it. You inherit some of your facial and other anatomical features.

Drugs & Medicines: Other things that can exacerbate sleep apnea include alcohol use and other sedating drugs or medicines. These can cause increased relaxation of the tissues that contribute to airway collapse, and also make the brain less sensitive to the signals that would normally cause someone to wake up and breathe.

https://www.barbellmedicine.com/blog/a-basic-guide-to-sleep-apnea/

Just cut out the fruits and veggies. Go pure carnivore for 60 days as an elimination diet, find your baseline with that very limited pool of foods, then add in new foods slowly to see how your body reacts to them. The most common one people do is BBBE (Beef, Butter, Bacon, Eggs) but some people like to go even further with only beef and butter.

I have psoriasis and I find that any amount of fruit, veggies, or grains flares it up, but your mileage may vary. It can be a long process to figure this shit out but it's worth it, only you can figure out what your body can and can't digest without issue, and elimination diets are the best way to accomplish that.

Basically paleo minus the tubors. I found a good paper on hunter gatherer dietary intake and it's something like 60% meat, 20% fruit, 10% potato 2% honey 2% seeds 2% cocks etc etc. Some groups, like the Hadza/hazda whatever eat all of their carbs as honey, like almost 800 calories a day in honey. They all eat a lot of meat. Hunter gatherers are the healthiest population on the entire planet, with the exception of their high infant and accidental and infectious mortality rates (obviously not dietary problems). They also likely reflect a bioevolutionary snapshot into what our species has been eating for hundreds of thousands of years which, at the very least, you can say is a diet which we have adapted to. Their fiber intake is astronomical, like twice our reccomended ideal intake.

Now logically, you can eat whatever as long as it works. Naturalistic fallacy and all that. But I think its hard to beat a hunter gatherer diet. I eat bread because I'm still poor-ish and fresh fruit and veg is expensive when done 24/7.

>>69239355
"Filter" is a bad word to use and doesn't capture the role of any organ, because it implies that molecules get trapped in that organ (like an air filter). Your liver detoxifies (i.e. destroys) molecules in the bloodstream that aren't native. This could be anything from toxins (deadly) to phytonutrients (deadly or having no effect, but never proven to be beneficial). The human liver is much stronger than a dog's, that's why we can eat chocolate, for instance, and not die like a dog or cat would.

The kidneys move toxins & byproducts of metabolism (like oxalates, a byproduct of urine production in humans and found in spinach functioning to store calcium) out of your blood and into your urine. I wouldn't really use the word "filter" to describe it because, again, nothing is getting stored or trapped in your kidneys.

I'm not sure, but I would think so. Heating may denature those enzymes. It's hard to find good honey at grocery stores, but if you just look for two things you'll always get good honey: "Raw" and "Made in the USA." Lots of honey is made in the USA but not raw or is raw but made out of a blend (and then you can't trust it, because "raw" could mean anything in Argentina). If you don't do this, you may buy honey that's either directly cut with sugar water or honey made from bees being fed sugar water (and not eating pollen).

Of course, you'll get the best honey from local apiaries. You might find one close to you. These are good websites:
https://www.localhoneyfinder.org/index.php
https://www.beeculture.com/find-local-beekeeper/

If you have multiple options near you, choose the one that doesn't spray their fields with Round-Up (glyphosates). You can ask them.

Imagine not knowing what bioavailability and digestibility are. Nutrients being present doesn't mean they will be absorbed and used. Calories in means what you absorb. Calories out means what you use. CICO is insufficient because it fails to account for metabolic variability and things like setpoint, hormones, etc. But it isn't wrong.

Let me preface this by saying that I'm neither for or against a stricter regulation of weapons in the USA. In fact I'd rather see the whole thing burn in thermonuclear fire, but that's neither here nor there.

Second point I'd like to make is that wearing a lightning rod to avoid lightning strike seems like a bad idea since the purpose of a lightning rod is to attract lightning strikes. A better idea would be to stand some distance away from a lightning rod, thereby ensuring that the lightning strikes the rod and not you.

Now onto the main point. A quick research allowed me to get the following figures:
Nb of school shootings in the USA since 2000: 402
Mean population of students in the USA since 2000: 77,500,000
Mean population of students in elementary and secondary school in the USA since 2000: 50,000,000
Nb of students injured in school shootings since 2000: 687
Nb of students killed in school shootings since 2000: 376
Thereby allowing us to figure out the following probabilities, considering the most conservative estimate:
Probability of being injured in a school shooting while being a student: ~0,000886% or odds of 1 in 1,127.
Probability of being killed in a school shooting while being a student: ~0,000485% or odds of 1 in 2,060.

Now for this part I didn't do the math myself, but it appears that the odds of being struck by lightning in the USA during your lifetime are of 1 in 15,300. This means that the current population of the USA has much higher odds of being involved in a school shooting than of being struck by lightning during their lifetime by an order of magnitude.

Thanks for coming to my TED Talk.

>>69249414
Yes. Go all the way down so your back hyperextends then contract abs as much as you can. You won't sit up all the way, but that range of motion is the important part and you don't give your abs time to rest like you do at the top of a normal sit-up. Shit burns a lot faster and is much easier to load than full ROM.

I got fired from a meme job a few days ago, was about to fall once again into a deep deppression, just like I have done mutiple times before when things get tough.
Not this time though. Even though I'm having a really hard time finding an engineering job (just graduated), and my expectations of a high paying and exciting job out of college have crumbled, I will get through this.

Wim hof meditation, going to the gym and reading funny and motivating shit from /fit/ is keeping me afloat. I will keep harnessing how little light there is right now in my life. I know harder times are ahead, and I WILL feel defeated and ready to give up, but I WILL NOT. I will honor my creator and become the best version of myself. I will forgive my past mistakes and wasted time. I will use those mistakes and regrets as a lesson for the future. So that one day I might inspire someone to also seek their true self.

I want to make my family proud, make my friends look at my unrelenting drive and be in awe, I want to break records, I want to be honored and recognized for innovation and excellence.

I want my future son/daughter to look back into my life and think of me as one bad motherfucker that overcame the odds and found the true path. I want them to recognize my efforts and be inspired by them so that they also follow the truth. I want them to nourish that ember of light and hope and pass it on to their friends and future family.

I want to be a man that left this world just a little better, just a little happier than what I received when I was born.

I want to chase my dreams, and I know all of you in this forum do so to. Lets do this bros, lets give the world our soul and will, and be a net positive for good.

All the love, all the power.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been trying to fix my life for 10 years now, with no success. I keep trying, I keep reworking my plan to try to find some way of making it work. Here's my current plan, any critique encouraged

>step one: healthy body healthy mind
>wake up at a reasonable hour, set alarm for 6 am and go to bed at 9pm
>do this for a week and then start eating at a proper time, breakfast at 6am, lunch at 12, dinner at 6pm
>do this for a week then start controlling the content of those meals, for a total of 1800 kcal a day
>do this for a week, then stop fapping, everytime you feel horny go for a walk instead
>do this for a week then start lifting weights 3x a week
Each step, one a time, adding onto another. Once all these things are sorted, my body will begin to improve, and then I can start working on my mind
>start studying for career path
>then after some time, once that becomes a habit, start engaging in hobbies and socialising and so on

I'm currently 2 days into step one, I work up at 6am today.
All these steps are based off what I believe to be the perfect balance between
>trying to fix your life all at once
vs
>baby steps
If you babystep too much, there is not enough progress to keep the momentum going, it doesn't feel like you're going anywhere. but if you try to fix everything all at once, it's too much and you give up from the pressure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some words for anyone here who has been struggling recently:
Life is not so simple that you are either perfect or broken; every single person on this Earth has their share of suffering and joy. It is foolish to see the presented joys of others and forget that there exists far more than you can imagine going on behind all that is shared in the public eye.
Cull your bad habits as you can, and cultivate good ones as you will. It is the choice of all to encourage or discourage their own behaviors, whether they realize it or not.
The soul is a garden in which the weeds of unhealthy behavior/mindset will continuously try to spring up, and if you do not nip them in the bud but let them overgrow then any good fruits you hope to harvest will wither away.
>>69234235
Persistence is the key to success in any endeavor, and following this sort of advice is a good way to build enduring persistence.
When people try to "fix" their life by tackling all of their issues at the same time, they are unable to fix anything. They become overwhelmed, exhausted, and demoralized. They lose persistence, and eventually give up with a mentality that "they gave it a shot but it just didn't work".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69239949
I was in the navy because the army recruiter sheboon kept playing games and the navy dude was straightforward. I just shot guns, drank, and partied honestly. You need to follow a program that revolves around becoming a ranger, again the navyseal subreddit has great training prgrams. Don't ever pay for any training source or book because it's all free online. Cardio and injury prevention are your very important as it doesn't matter if you can max out push-ups when you get gassed early during a ruck or you fuck your joints up. Do strength training as well like greyskull or some shit.The recruiter should have a special programs trainer that helps you get in shape, at least the navy recruiter did. Ask the recruiter if you need to pass a prerequisite physical test before getting a ranger contract and shipping out to basic. Test yourself now and see what areas you need to improve on, don't settle for bare minimum scores, you need to be as close to max as possible so you have enough of a buffer when you're being tested. I'm not sure how much more help I can offer besides telling you that all the people I've met in special programs whether they were seals, eod, rangers, or faggoty ass divers and aircrew loved it despite going through some tough ass training.

Cardio doesn't make you lose weight. You only lose weight based on your diet. You need to be eating the most satiating and nutrient-dense foods (meat, organs, fruit) and avoiding anything with an ingredients list.

I would also recommend 36 hour fasts on days you don't do physically or mentally intensive (if you plan to spend a Saturday at home cleaning, for instance), because I personally really like them.

posts.com:
>>69247783
As for lifting, you should only be doing exercises that work out a lot of muscles at once at this moment in time. Don't over think it. Just do this

>squats
>pull-ups
>bench press
>overhead press
>rows (any type you like)
>deadlift/deadlift alternative (don't be a spaz with this exercise)

However many days you work out, split those lifts evenly. If you work out 3 days, pick 2 of those lifts, do 3 sets of 5 with 2 sets of warm-ups, and then do a couple complementary lifts. For instance:
>Monday squat/bench press day
>squats
>bulgarian split squats
>bench press
>dips

That is literally all you need to be doing at this point in time. Do not overcomplicate it. If you want more examples or a full program for lifting 3x a week, let me know.

>>69232040
Keto is good for short-medium periods of time where you can be fairly strict and avoid "keto friendly" foods. Personally I like to do 6-8wks and I try for twice a year. Just eat good food and stick to real food. Eat lots of vegetables.

In between keto eat lots of fruits and vegetables.

Its been really good to me. I adapt to keto pretty well so I can go into ketosis pretty quickly with a 24hr fast. I generally lose weight without tracking my calories, but I do eat reasonably. It also shrinks my stomach a little bit because I eat less food volume wise. Its great for me to hit the reset button on my diet if my sweet tooth starts to get a little out of hand. I also read an article about preliminary studies indicating keto can disrupt the growth of certain kinds of tumors. Basically, your organs adapt to ketones pretty quickly, but tumors do not so the adaption period they tend to not do well and that "layer" can hamper its growth.

All this keeps me coming back to keto once or twice a year for 6wks or so. In pretty good shape for a 35 year oldfag
